item.title: By: Matt White
item.dc:creator: Matt White
item.description: <p>@Patrick,</p><p>See my comments above in @2, but I do agree with you, when the virtualisation software matches my requirements I'll be junking the Windows partition. My big hope is for OS X 1.5 (Leopard) which sound slike it will do exactly what I'm after. Until then I boot into Windows in the morning, use that during the day and then for evenings and weekends (when I do my own work) I use OS X and Parallels where necessary.</p><p>Until we get the Hannover based Domino Designer client I am really tied to using Windows for my day job unfortunately.</p><p>Matt</p>
item.content:encoded:
@Patrick,

See my comments above in @2, but I do agree with you, when the virtualisation software matches my requirements I’ll be junking the Windows partition. My big hope is for OS X 1.5 (Leopard) which sound slike it will do exactly what I’m after. Until then I boot into Windows in the morning, use that during the day and then for evenings and weekends (when I do my own work) I use OS X and Parallels where necessary.

Until we get the Hannover based Domino Designer client I am really tied to using Windows for my day job unfortunately.

Matt

item.title: By: Patrick Corey
item.dc:creator: Patrick Corey
item.description: <p>I don't see the benefit doing a dual boot. I think virtualization is going to be more powerful. Parallels is able to run VMWARE images as well as Virtual PC/Server. VMWare is approximately $200 and when a product costing about $40 is compatible, I think that is a good deal.<br/><br/><br/><br/>Virtualization seems to be more appealing when you have the right hardware. Knowing how efficient the MacBook Pro is running Virtualization seems to be a perfect match and I am not giving up disk space or inhibit from access files in the Mac or the guest environment.<br/><br/><br/><br/>Cheers..</p>
item.content:encoded:
I don’t see the benefit doing a dual boot. I think virtualization is going to be more powerful. Parallels is able to run VMWARE images as well as Virtual PC/Server. VMWare is approximately $200 and when a product costing about $40 is compatible, I think that is a good deal.

Virtualization seems to be more appealing when you have the right hardware. Knowing how efficient the MacBook Pro is running Virtualization seems to be a perfect match and I am not giving up disk space or inhibit from access files in the Mac or the guest environment.

Cheers..

item.title: By: David Vasta
item.dc:creator: David Vasta
item.description: <p>Very Cool! Saving Money Now. My iBook is great but a 17" MacBook PRO would be AWESOME!!!!!</p>
item.content:encoded: Very Cool! Saving Money Now. My iBook is great but a 17″ MacBook PRO would be AWESOME!!!!!

item.title: By: Damien Barnard
item.dc:creator: Damien Barnard
item.description: <p>I knew you'd eventually come back from the darkside. <img src="<a rel="nofollow ugc">http://www.11tmr.com/11tmr.nsf/emoticons/DLYH-5MZVLY/$FILE/smile.gif"</a>> How much "snappier" does it feel than your previous machine?</p>
item.content:encoded: I knew you’d eventually come back from the darkside. http://www.11tmr.com/11tmr.nsf/emoticons/DLYH-5MZVLY/$FILE/smile.gif“> How much “snappier” does it feel than your previous machine?

item.title: By: Ben Poole
item.dc:creator: Ben Poole
item.description: <p>Re Leopard, that's what I understand too... Boot Camp is a simply a beta preview of the core technology they intend to use in Leopard.</p><p>In retrospect, it makes sense for Apple to do this, given that once upon a time, MS controlled the only other viable solution for all this (i.e. Virtual PC).</p>
item.content:encoded:
Re Leopard, that’s what I understand too… Boot Camp is a simply a beta preview of the core technology they intend to use in Leopard.

In retrospect, it makes sense for Apple to do this, given that once upon a time, MS controlled the only other viable solution for all this (i.e. Virtual PC).

item.title: By: Matt White
item.dc:creator: Matt White
item.description: <p>I do have the pre release candidate for Parallels, it's really just Virtual PC on steroids and very useful if you just want to try something quickly or are forced to use IE for a website. But having played with it for a few hours there are a few niggles (mainly to do with the speed of the UI) which would annoy me if I had to use it for a full working week. Of course it's still beta software as well so it may well improve but at the moment the rebooting across into Windows suits me fine.</p><p>If I understand the rumours coming out about Leopard then you'll be able to run both OS's at the same time without the need for rebooting which sounds just superb.</p>
item.content:encoded:
I do have the pre release candidate for Parallels, it’s really just Virtual PC on steroids and very useful if you just want to try something quickly or are forced to use IE for a website. But having played with it for a few hours there are a few niggles (mainly to do with the speed of the UI) which would annoy me if I had to use it for a full working week. Of course it’s still beta software as well so it may well improve but at the moment the rebooting across into Windows suits me fine.

If I understand the rumours coming out about Leopard then you’ll be able to run both OS’s at the same time without the need for rebooting which sounds just superb.

item.title: By: Ben Poole
item.dc:creator: Ben Poole
item.description: <p>I am very envious <img src="<a rel="nofollow ugc">http://www.11tmr.com/11tmr.nsf/emoticons/DLYH-5MZVLY/$FILE/smile.gif"</a>> If I ever went on my own and needed my own kit, this is exactly what I would do.</p><p>Are you tempted to try the Parallels software? That way you can run the OSes side-by-side.</p><p>Do keep us updated re progress with this set-up!</p>
item.content:encoded:
I am very envious http://www.11tmr.com/11tmr.nsf/emoticons/DLYH-5MZVLY/$FILE/smile.gif“> If I ever went on my own and needed my own kit, this is exactly what I would do.

Are you tempted to try the Parallels software? That way you can run the OSes side-by-side.

Do keep us updated re progress with this set-up!
